title: Shared key exchange (still) busted in version 1.8.4
comment: Seems that the key exchange problem has somewhat morphed in version 1.8.4.  Now, periodically, the following message appears: "Hostkey signature sent by remote is wrong!"  Usually, another attempt resolves the issue.  Itseems less chronic than the prior signed/unsigned shared secret encoding, but is still occurring nonetheless. (prior review follows)...   For those suffering with the message "Key exchange was not finished, connection is closed." when attempting to connect to a server -- try repeatedly connecting.  It appears that there is a bug in 1.8.3 that causes this when the shared secret is encoded as a negative value.  Subsequent connections will eventually work (provided that rules on your server do not blacklist you first).  It appears that the bug has been fixed by the developers but has yet to be released.  A small blemish on an otherwise great app.
Thanks for the public service announcemeunt. The fix for this was released in 1.8.4. :)

Connections are real shaky, to the point where I cannot connect to a windows box running Bitvise's SSH Server at all. (Prior to the update ConnectBot connected to everything.) ES File Explorer has no issues importing keys from there, and ConnectBot will save them to there (and subsequently use them), it just makes no attempt to use any keys it doesn't generate from there (actually, it did generate them on another device, but that's beside the point).

title: Was an essential part of my daily Android experience
comment: For accessing my home computers, computers at work or for bringing up a shell on the phone itself (in conjunction with Superuser to get root), I found this app was an essential part of my daily Android experience.  Over time, as I got an external bluetooth keyboard, and needed to do more things, I found that it wasn't keeping up. It was a great app when it first came out I'm sure, and as a first terminal client it really fit the bill. Unfortunately it seems like it's been orphaned since 2010... at least judging by the last update date here, and well, things have moved on. It still talks about phones that have a joystick or trackball.  I think this app'll probably remain great for people with older phones... but for people with newer phones or bluetooth keyboards, JuiceSSH is probably going to fit the bill better.

Could *really* do with the ability to back up and restore host configuration and keys, though; on moving to a new phone, I can find no easy way to transfer the stored host connection details (including numerous port forwards, etc) and private key - if the device was rooted I could get at the data, but since it's currently not rooted, and the app provides no way to back up & restore, looks like I'll have to re-enter all the details on the new device.  Also, consider checking out VX ConnectBot, also on the market, which is based on ConnectBot but includes extra features.

title: Nice ssh client.
comment: Using a phone, I've been able to log in to a machine, edit some C code, test, write a ChangeLog entry and commit!  Those who think they need arrow keys should learn how to use vi, and vi edit modes in shells: hjkl are your friend. Handling of closed connections is silly. You get a dialog which says "Host has disconnected. Close session?"  The choices are simply Yes or No. If you say Yes, the program quits. If you say no, it stays running with the frozen session and all you can do is go to the menu and hit Disconnect. A better behavior would be for the program to not bring up any dialog at all, since there is already a "connection lost" message in the text window. In this situation, the menu should reconfigure itself: the Disconnect and Port Forwards buttons (which are not applicable in a disconnected state) should be replaced with Quit and Reconnect buttons.  The touch mechanism for sending control characters could be extended so that common control characters like Ctrl-C, and Tab (or the user's recently used control codes) can be sent with a single tap. Maybe a whole transparent virtual keyboard should be shown which sends only control keys, Esc and others.

title: Would be great, but missing important keys.
comment: Connects to servers quickly and easily. Plus, it keeps track of hosts which makes connecting even easier when you connect host over and over again.  I frequently SSH into the computer science lab machines at my school to work on projects. All I have to do is tap on the host, enter my password, and I'm in.  The only problem is that I can't use certain keys. For example, there's no way to do a Control key without a trackball. Since there's no trackball on my Asus Transformer, I can't use the Control key at all. This is a serious problem when working in Linux shells. Even more so, since I use Nano to edit code and need CTRL+X to save and exit. For this, I'm taking off two stars.  Pro: easy and fast connectivity.  Con: Missing important keys on devices without a trackball.   If it's updated to include full support for full keyboards (the Transformer has a control key on the keyboard dock) I will change my review up to five stars.

Using these two together, your SSH experience is almost even better than being on the server yourself in a shell! its slick.   definitely recommended!  So funny, this app is so good, and used by so many, that others rip off the name! there are like 4 others that use the name! make sure to get this one so you know you are getting the real deal!  OH! and get the app "Orientation Control" so you can use this app with hackers keyboard smoothly. You can force it into Landscape. Hackers Keyboard only preforms well in landscape, otherwise there are so many tiny buttons you hit more than one at a time! It works great with the extra room on a mobile device in landscape!
